mesh4d.obj3d.Obj3d#

class mesh4d.obj3d.Obj3d(filedir: str = '', scale_rate: float = 1, mode: str = 'load')[source]#

Bases: object

The basic 3D object class. Loads .obj 3D mesh image and sampled it as the point cloud.

Parameters

  • filedir – the direction of the 3D object.

  • scale_rate –

    the scaling rate of the 3D object.

    Attention

    Noted that the original unit of 3dMD raw data is millimetre (mm). The default scale_rate remains this unit.

    See also

    Reason for providing scale_rate parameter is explained in Obj3d_Deform.

  • mode –

    • load the default mode is load from a file.

    • empty create a 3D object without any 3D data.

Note

Class Attributes

self.mesh_o3d

3D mesh (open3d.geometry.TriangleMesh) loaded with open3d .

self.pcd

3D point cloud (open3d.geometry.PointCloud) sampled from self.mesh_o3d.

self.scale_rate

the scaling rate of the 3dMD model.

Attention

In future development, mesh may also be loaded with pyvista as self.mesh_pv, for its advantages in visualisation and some specific geometric analysis features.

Example

from mesh4d import obj3d
o3 = obj3d.Obj3d(
    filedir = 'data/6kmh_softbra_8markers_1/speed_6km_soft_bra.000001.obj',
)
o3.show()
__init__(filedir: str = '', scale_rate: float = 1, mode: str = 'load')[source]#

show_diff(obj2[, cmap, op2])

Illustrate the difference of two 3D object:
show()[source]#

Show the loaded mesh and the sampled point cloud.

Attention

Before calling this method in Jupyter Notebook environment, the pythreejs backend of pyvista is needed to be selected:

import pyvista as pv
pv.set_jupyter_backend('pythreejs')
show_diff(obj2: Type[mesh4d.obj3d.Obj3d], cmap: str = 'cool', op2: float = 0.2)[source]#

Illustrate the difference of two 3D object:

obj1 mesh will be coloured according to each of its points’ distance to obj2 mesh. The mapping between distance and color is controlled by cmap argument. Noted that in default setting, light bule indicates small deformation and purple indicates large deformation.

Parameters

  • obj1 – the first 3D object.

  • obj2 – the second 3D object.

  • cmap –

    the color map name.

    See also

    For full list of supported color map, please refer to Choosing Colormaps in Matplotlib.

  • op2 – the opacity of the second 3D object.

add_mesh_to_scene(scene: pyvista.plotting.plotting.Plotter, location: numpy.array = array([0, 0, 0]), show_edges: bool = True, **kwargs) → pyvista.plotting.plotting.Plotter[source]#

Add the visualisation of the mesh to a pyvista.Plotter scene.

Parameters

  • scene – pyvista.Plotter scene to add the visualisation.

  • location – the displace location represented in a (3, ) numpy.array.

  • show_edges – show mesh edges or not

  • **kwargs –

    other visualisation parameters.

    See also

    pyvista.Plotter.add_mesh pyvista.Plotter.add_points

Returns

pyvista.Plotter scene added the visualisation.

Return type

pyvista.Plotter
